title: Mr. Knife, Miss Fork
text: The German artist Max Ernst was a pioneering figure in both the Dada and Surrealist movements of the early 20th century. In addition to his many other achievements, he collaborated with American artist Man Ray in developing the photogram, essentially a photograph made without the need for a camera or lens. Among his most inspired images, the photograms included in this artist's book were made by combining frottage (textural rubbings) and line drawings on sheets of thin translucent paper, then using those sheets of paper as photographic negatives to create a reverse image on photosensitive paper. The text is Kay Boyle's English translation of the first chapter of Ren√© Crevel's novel Babylone (1927).
creditline: The Ethel Morrison Van Derlip Fund and Gift of funds from the Print and Drawing Council
